labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Add a pointer to RFC 7807 in the abstract
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: The abstract should also point to RFC 7807 so that people who understand that problem set will also be able to find this one.

issues.title: The "x dash" problem
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Context: RFC 6648, in particular the analysis in [Appendix B](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6648#appendix-B)

The problem is if the producer never updates to the public format, consumers – not just CoAP clients but the whole logging pipeline – need to cope for an indefinite amount of time.

Unfortunately, consumers don’t seem to have much leverage.

We define a private-to-public migration plan from the onset, but to what extent is that effective in preventing the problem?

We need to provide discussion on strategies for minimising the risk of “eternal pollution” (e.g., use an automated software update mechanism.)

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: -04 of course still has a form of the x-dash problem (for custom problem details entries), but it is minimized as far as we can by strictly separating the "play as I like" space (URIs) from the registered space (numbers).  It is not clear how this can be further improved.

issues.title: Localisation of string fields
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
How do we handle localisation of text strings?

Some options:
* Force a language (en-us? inuktitut?)
* Add language tags to strings (e.g., a la [CoRAL](https://www.ietf.org/id/draft-ietf-core-coral-03.html#section-6.5))
* "the windows logs" way as suggested by Jim: _"In some ways the method that is used by Windows to log events works out pretty well, but might be too weighty for this.  In that case a list of information with the title and a set of attributes are returned from the server (event) and these are then placed into a localized string.  It might be possible to provide a default string, a set of attributes and a method of getting a localized string if needed."_

comments.author: ektrah
comments.body: See [Expressing Natural Language Texts in CoRAL](https://www.ietf.org/id/draft-ietf-core-coral-03.html#name-expressing-natural-language)

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: This could be handled by CBOR tags, maybe an update of tag 38

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> This could be handled by CBOR tags, maybe an update of tag 38

http://peteroupc.github.io/CBOR/langtags.html

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: Anything we do for CoRAL that extends this to directions would apply directly here, whether it's in the form of a new tag or a compatible extension to the old one.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
or go our own way to avoid deps:

```
text-string = text / intl-text

intl-text = {
  0: text                  ; text 
  1: text                  ; lang tag
  ? 2: bool .default true. ; ltr or rtl
}
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Dealt with in [e4d1dd2](https://github.com/core-wg/core-problem-details/pull/16/commits/e4d1dd27d66e6a310eddc0e86eeefb40fb9e2b7b) (#16)

issues.title: Feature: Tracing / diagnostics
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Jim suggested subsuming CoAP's diagnostic payload under the problem structure.  This would mean adding another optional diagnostic key to the base fields.

Christian> [summary] _"details and diagnostic are mutually exclusive; handle diagnostic as an extension"_ -- see also the [original email.](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/aypkvGo5fnBGrWUTtAJAVBz5BBE/)

I think the question is: is this going to be common enough that is worth factoring it out proactively?  Needs discussion.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
One thing that needs to be factored in this specific feature, and more generally in the PD discussion, is that there exist not only one but potentially two different PD consumers.  On one side it’s the obvious CoAP client, on the other — especially when the CoAP server or CoAP API gateway is found in an (edge) cloud — a logging and analytics pipeline that collects, filters, presents log messages coming from a potentially huge number of different servers and transactions.

I think adding a separate “tracing/diagnostic“ instead of making a more verbose “details” (which, might be a perfectly valid alternative in many cases) is better understood from the latter angle.  The use case I have in mind is an already deployed server that is temporarily put in "tracing mode" to diagnose a failure.  There, having a separate channel for the tracing info instead of having to write an ad-hoc filter to extract the relevant information from the “details” field is a much better alternative (i.e., easier to ingest & process).  Cost-wise, from a PD producer perspective there would be no added overheads.  From the PoV of the transport, there’s a slight increase in bandwidth to support the extra structuring but I'd expect it to be dwarfed by the diagnostic payload anyway.

issues.title: Segregate extensions in a sub-map
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
We don't want the following situation to arise:

1. a private API defines its own extension code point 5
2. in the meantime the same codepoint 5 has been registered in the "global" fields 
3 the API now goes public (i.e., it grabs a public namespace code point)
4. the private codepoint and the global codepoint clash!

Caveat implementor! Extension fields need to be segregated in a sub-map instead of sharing the same space as the base fields.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: CoRAL should fix this automatically.

issues.title: Ready-to-use Problem Detail types
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
We should provide a default set of ready-to-use PD types associated with the existing CoAP status codes, intended for carrying (and enriching) the associated status code semantics.

The (rough) plan is to define an “about:coap” namespace with one PD type for each registered [4.xx and 5.xx status code](https://www.iana.org/assignments/core-parameters/core-parameters.xhtml#response-codes).

An application could use such PDs without the need to register anything.  Just pick the "right" type and populate the relevant fields, job done.

As a nice side-effect, this would allow exercising the registration procedure, including the definition of the PD type's registry structure and providing a first set of registrations.

issues.title: Feature: Response codes
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
CoAP Response Codes are an optional feature and should be discussed in a separate section.

**Rationale for the feature**
The CoAP response-code is already carried by the CoAP header, so it doesn't make sense adding it to the PD payload that goes from Server to Client.

It does however make sense for a Client that is about to ingest the received PD into a log pipeline to "enrich" it with ancillary Information from the underlying CoAP transaction.

In this context, response-code is probably the most basic attribute that one wants to carry over as it is also commonly used as a high-level partition key for log visualisation.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: addressed by #16

issues.title: Feature: 3rd party error reporting
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
We discussed the "API gateway" use case where one or more "data centre" backend errors needs to be reported to the client.

Is this a popular enough use case to deserve its own field in the basic part of the map?

Discuss!

comments.author: thomas-fossati
cabo
comments.body: On the solution side, composability in the unbundled model (#16) goes a long way, here.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
no need to treat this as a separate use case.

> Composability in the unbundled model goes a long way, here.

no need to treat this as a separate use case.

issues.title: Design goals for protocol elements identification
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
The variables that needs optimising are:
- size/compactness of IDs
- low barrier to entry
- stability
- private-public transitions
- popularity/familiarity to REST API developers
we don't consider any existing solution that doesn't prevent collisions

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
Hooking into the request for suggestions in today's presentation (not all points mine but from the meeting):
* Registration at IANA might in future be as easy as a GitHub PR
* Still, we can't expect developers to register every single exception they create.
  * Something hierarchical would solve this. If identifiers (in their expanded form) are URI based, registering a shortcut for a base might allow developers to register their application base and then use codes below that.
* What if a registrant goes away?
  * What if a registrant does updates in incompatible ways?
  * When URI based, same problem as with uncompressed references that are based on DNS. Registrants may prefer to use other URI schemes (eg. URNs without DNS names).

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: all of the stated design goals are addressed by the design in #16.  The only leftover is "private-public transition" which is tracked by #2

issues.title: Localisation of the "title" field
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
We currently say that a value for "title" needs to be specified when registering a new “type".

This requires the registering party to make an upfront decision with regards to the language to use.  

(Note that the more general question about localisation of text fields is tracked by #3)

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: This is an instance of #3

issues.title: alignment with rfc7807bis
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
The HTTPAPI WG has very recently adopted the rfc7807bis document.  We should monitor what happens there and make sure we  any "lesson learned" in the HTTP world is picked up and digested.

More context:
* [IETF 110 presentation](https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/110/materials/slides-110-httpapi-rfc-8707bis-problem-details-00.pdf)
* [RFC7807-bis editor's copy](https://github.com/ietf-wg-httpapi/rfc7807bis)

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: IETF110 presentation: Dead link

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/110/materials/slides-110-httpapi-rfc-7807bis-problem-details-00.pdf

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
The "tunnelling" aspects regarding the 7807->CPD direction have been dealt with in [74cdbf1](https://github.com/core-wg/core-problem-details/pull/16/commits/74cdbf1854d392321ff20a0d5765108a60c20778) (#16)

Until 7807bis is finalised we won't be able to assemble the whole toolkit that is needed to handle the CPD->7807 direction.  This has been noted in the text.

issues.title: Marco's review
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/7_Oqt82j4tl69IG6--FrSoRN8uQ/

```
[Section 1.1]

* Please add the usual remark "Readers are expected to be familiar with ..."


[Section 2]

* The caption of Figure 2 can better say "Concise Problem Details Data 
Item".

* The definition of the 'title' entry says: "It SHOULD NOT change from 
occurrence to occurrence of the problem."

    Do you mean "of the same problem" ?

* The definition of 'response-code' can be expanded to also point to 
Section 3 of RFC 7252, and explicitly say that the response code here is 
exactly the value of the 'Code' field in the header of the CoAP 
response. This would complement the statement and example in the last 
paragraph of the section.

* When defining the entry 'response-code', it is good to have a pointer 
also to Section 3.2 of RFC 8132, thus covering also 4.09 and 4.22.

* "Note that, unlike [RFC7807], Concise Problem Details data items have 
no explicit type."

Consistently, please consider the following changes to avoid possible 
confusion:

    - In Section 1, use "problem classes" rather than "problem types".

    - In Section 2, use "summary of the problem class" rather than 
"summary of the problem type" when defining the 'title' entry. A few 
paragraphs below, "shorthand for the category of the error" can also 
become "shorthand for the class of the error".

    - In Section 3, use "generic problem class container" rather than 
"generic problem type container".

    - In Section 5.1, as to the "Brief description" for 'title' in Table 
1, use "problem class" rather than "problem type".


[Section 3.1]

* "Consumers of a Concise Problem Details instance MUST ignore ..."

    I think it is better to use "data item" rather than "instance". That 
would be consistent with the text in other sections and would avoid 
confusion with the 'instance' entry.


[Section 3.2]

* "Consumers of a Concise Problem Details instance MUST ignore ..."

    See the comment above about using "data item" rather than "instance".

* Is it admitted to change the definition of an already existing Custom 
Problem Details entry, by updating the related documentation? Or is it 
something to discourage or even forbid, rather preferring a new entry to 
be defined altogether?


[Section 5.1]

* For 'title' and 'detail', shouldn't the CDDL Type be "text/array", 
rather than "text"? If tag 38 is used, that applies to an array, as per 
Appendix A.2.


[Nits]

* Section 3.1, s/so they never can/so they can never

* Section 3.2, s/the nested map any/the nested map, any

* Section 3.2, s/for extension that/for extensions that

* Section 3.2, s/compact representation, in/compact representation. In

* Section 3.2, s/principle, MUST NOT be/principle, it MUST NOT be

* Section 5.1, s/Entries in Standard/Entries in the Standard

* Section 5.2, s/Entries in Custom/Entries in the Custom

* Table 1/2/3, s/RFCXXXX/RFC XXXX

* Appendix B (2 instances), s/Concise Problem Details item/Concise 
Problem Details data item

* Appendix B (2 instances), s/Custom Problem Detail entry/Custom Problem 
Details entry
```

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Closed by #18.

issues.title: SHOULD
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
_Comment by @fpalombini_

[Section 2](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-core-problem-details-04.html#section-2):

> ~~~ 
 A short, human-readable summary of the problem shape.  It SHOULD
 NOT change from occurrence to occurrence of the same problem
 shape.
~~~
Needs some context around why this is a SHOULD and what are the reasonable cases and consequences of this recommendation not being followed.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
(w/ TF:)

The current text "SHOULD be stable across instances" is copied from RFC 7807.
This made sense when this was basically a human readable version of type, i.e., a shorthand for
the problem type. 
But the problem type has been subsumed by the problem shape.
Probably better to cut short at "A short, human-readable summary of the problem shape."
Maybe we could add "SHOULD not try to summarize the information given with the problem details", i.e., the summary might include that the account does not have enough money, but not how much money it has and how much would be needed.

issues.title: Untagged text strings for human readable text
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
_Comment by @fpalombini_

[Section 2](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-core-problem-details-04.html#section-2):

> Both "title" and "detail" can use either an unadorned CBOR text string (text) or a language-tagged text string (tag38); see Appendix A for the definition of the latter.

I have a hard time motivating why this can be unadorned CBOR text string, given that these two fields are always human-readable text. Maybe we need to add a default, i.e. that when text used, that is to be interpreted as English language is used.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
(w/ TF:)

making "foo" a shorthand for 38(["en", "foo", false]) makes sense in the Anglo-American dominated world we live in.
 
Details (en? en-US?) need to be discussed though.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Details (en? en-US?) need to be discussed though.

I wouldn't go down the rabbit hole of also picking the locale.  Too much stress 😅 

I'm happy with the minimum required to satisfy the `langtag` rule, i.e., "en".

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
In [yesterday's interim](https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/interim-2022-core-08/materials/slides-interim-2022-core-08-sessa-carstens-slides-00#page=4) we decided to go with the following:
1. use context if available
2. fall back to english


Now, similar to `base-uri`, should we have a `lang` (and `dir`) keys for when the CPD is stored/forwarded and therefore the context is lost?

issues.title: More examples
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
_Comment by @fpalombini_

It would be nice with an example in [Section 3.1](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-core-problem-details-04.html#section-3.1) as well.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
I’m not sure we actually need one (there are 5 predefined now).
Inventing one always has this problem that people start using it from the example, so there is a threshold of usefulness before one includes an example that is not actually registered.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Actually, #32 is an attempt to provide an example that is actually useful to register.

issues.title: Example's format
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
_Comment by @fpalombini_

[Section 3.2](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-core-problem-details-04.html#section-3.2):

> An example of a custom extension using a URI as custom-problem- detail-entries key is shown in Figure 3.

Please explicitly state that the example (or examples if you add one in [Section 3.1](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-core-problem-details-04.html#section-3.1)) uses CBOR diagnostic notation.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Fixed in #20.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Closed by 7463ce1

issues.title: "like this"
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
_Comment by @fpalombini_

[Section 3.2](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-core-problem-details-04.html#section-3.2):

> ~~~ 
   /example value 4711 not actually registered like this:/
~~~
I don't get the sentence above - if this is to highlight that this is an example and that the value 4711 is not actually registered, I think this is redundant (and you could also add that in the Figure caption rather than in the example's text).

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
See #23: The danger that people are just blindly copying an example is just too high.  
So we would prefer to keep this redundant comment in.
We could improve the wording of the comment.

issues.title: Reference for tunnel-7807 registration
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
_Comment by @fpalombini_

[Section 5.2](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-core-problem-details-04.html#section-5.2):

> ~~~ 
 +=======+=============+===========================+===========+
 | 7807  | tunnel-7807 | Carry RFC 7807 problem    | RFC XXXX  |
 |       |             | details in a Concise      |           |
 |       |             | Problem Details data item |           |
 +-------+-------------+---------------------------+-----------+
~~~
Please change the reference to "RFC XXXX, Appendix B".

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Closed by ccbbd69

issues.title: Initial SPD suggestion: "offending option number"
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
Just having run into a a Bad Option response that was hard to debug without attaching a literal debugger to the program under test (because for some reason all the communication on the net is nowadays encrypted), I'd like to suggest one option for inclusion in the original problem details set:

* Name: Unprocessed CoAP option
* CDDL type: uint | [+uint]
* Brief description: CoAP option number that was not understood
* Longer description: A CoAP option number present in the request that could not be processed by the server. It may be a critical option that the server is unaware of, or an option the server is aware of but could not process (and chose not to, or was not allowed to, ignore it). Several options may be given in a list (in no particular order), without any guarantee that the list is complete (as the server might have stopped processing already at the first problematic option). If an option with the given number was repeated, there is no indication which of the values caused the fault. Clients need to expect seeing options in there they did not send in the request; this can happen if the request traversed a proxy that added the option but did not act on the problem details response. Note that for a few special values of unprocessed CoAP options (such as Accept or Proxy-Uri), there are special response codes (4.06 Not Acceptable, 5.05 Proxying Not Supported, respectively) to be sent instead. For future compatibility, receivers should ignore values not matching the current CDDL type, as these might be used to indicate an option more precisely if the demand arises.

A typical error response with this can be rather short -- just 4.02, 1+2 byte content format, and 3 bytes of CBOR data for option numbers up to 23.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
CDDL type probably more like `one-or-more<uint>`, where 

``` 
   one-or-more<T> = T / [ 2* T ]
``` 

Should we throw this in now or add this registration later?

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
This case appears to be the only one where RFC 7252 explicitly recommends a diagnostic payload.

The policy is specification required, so we could simply write this up as a document in this repo and register from there.  Of course, including it in the RFC provides more visibility.

pulls.title: Feature status codes
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body: Note that this PR sits on top of #12

pulls.title: 3GPP stop-gap version
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body:
The problem-details specification has been parked for a while waiting
for CoRAL to complete.
In the meantime, 3GPP has written the problem-details specification
into their client-server specifications and is expecting to cut a
release in June 2022.
It is unlikely that the CoRAL is complete by then, which would cause
problem-details to be written out of the specification (and probably
be replaced by an ad-hoc mechanism).

This PR proposes to define a concise problem details structure that
is simple enough so it can be completed within a couple of months.
This would keep the problem details approach within the 3GPP system
and will allow us to add a more complete CoRAL version later.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Subsumed (and replaced) by #16

We should probably make it explicit in the type it's URI reference rather than a generic string.

Besides, there should be a default value -- RFC7808 has `about:blank` -- that can be assumed by consumers if not present.
Since everything is optional but we don't want this to be an empty bag, we could wrap this is a `non-empty<M> = (M) .and ({ + any => any })`
Ditto, URI reference.

Not sure about this strategy, it seems to lead to a proliferation of tag registrations.  I think sub-typing should be done by the `title` attribute.  We could register a certain URI to be the base for standard extensions that go through the IANA path, and leave the rest of the URI space open to custom extensions.
Ditto for the `title`.
See my comment above about an alternative to handle extensibility.

Hi Thomas,

in the current draft, `title` is not a URI, but human-readable text, so I don't understand several of your comments.  In the PR, there actually is no way to put in a URI for the problem type (≠ title).

Arg, sorry, I need more powerful reading glasses apparently.  I merged "type" and "title" into one thing.  Please re-interpret all my comments as "can we rather use an explicit URI `type` attribute instead of the CBOR tag to handle extensibility?"
scratch this.
s/title/type/
scratch this.
Of course we could.  The idea with the PR was that many of these types work better if registered, and we have a nice registry that we can use for that.
UX question: are we saying that *all* extensions (including `custom-problem-detail-entries`) need to go through IANA, or does that apply to `standard-problem-detail-entries` only?

On standard problem details (which is what makes them different from custom ones), not custom ones (these are defined by the type).
We should say this more explicitly.
Yep: a3dd0fe

> We should say this more explicitly.

In sec-new-attributes we say _"To establish a *custom* problem type, A CBOR Tag number needs to be registered"_, which is confusing given we are referring to `standard-problem-detail-entries` rather than `custom-problem-detail-entries`

Regarding handling `custom-problem-detail-entries`: it is not clear to me how a receiver is supposed to distinguish between custom map entry "A" (e.g., w/ key 10) from custom map entry "B" (again w/ key 10) without an explicit type/sub-type/namespacing indication.

> In sec-new-attributes we say "To establish a custom problem type, A CBOR Tag number needs to be registered", which is confusing given we are referring to standard-problem-detail-entries rather than custom-problem-detail-entries

I think "custom problem type" was intended to be in contrast with the predefined Generic Problem Details type. The sentence can be rephrased as "To establish a new problem type different than the Generic Problem Details type defined in this specification, a CBOR Tag number needs to be registered".

> Regarding handling custom-problem-detail-entries: it is not clear to me how a receiver is supposed to distinguish between custom map entry "A" (e.g., w/ key 10) from custom map entry "B" (again w/ key 10) without an explicit type/sub-type/namespacing indication.

As I understand, the new tag comes with exactly one corresponding unique uint/tstr key, so there is no risk of collision as long as uniqueness is ensured (bottom line, when registering the new tag). As defined in sec-new-attributes:

"Problem type definitions MAY extend the Problem Details document with additional entries to convey additional, problem-specific information. These receive a custom problem detail entry map key (unsigned integer
or text) and SHOULD be described in a specification that goes along with such a registration.  Such a specification SHOULD also reference the present specification."

About the uniqueness of those map keys, this would mean that the review of a new tag registration has to also check that the new specification is indeed introducing a still available entry map key for the new custom problem detail. Is there a better way than checking all the documents that have registered a tag for custom problem details? Perhaps the map key can be mentioned in the "Semantics" column of the tag registry when registering the tag?

Well, not sub-typing but typing is done through `type`, only that the indication is now coming from a tag rather than a field.

Actually, applying multiple tags would allow to have a multi-type problem details item, including the custom-problem-detail entry corresponding to each tag different than the one for the predefined Generic Problem Details type.
See above about how to make it feasible to ensure uniqueness of map keys.
s/to be use/to be used
To be sure, does this hold even for the three entries `title`, `detail` and `instance` defined in this document? Or are they expected to be always recognized as minimally supported standard keys?
I don't understand this idea.  Can you provide an example?  BTW, 7807bis is moving away from trying to handle multi-type problems: https://github.com/ietf-wg-httpapi/rfc7807bis/pull/37/files

TLDR: please scratch it.

I was wondering how to possibly use multiple problem-type tags back to back to attain a multi type item, but I see that it's better to stick to one type only. Maybe it's better to mention explicitly that an item has a single problem-detail type, hence it comes with a single tag of that kind.

Also, my points above on ensuring uniqueness of keys become moot; even if the uint/tstr namespace of two different custom types overlap, the item will refer to only one of such namespace anyway (besides the single and global nint namespace for standard keys).

> These receive a map key

I suppose you don't mean exactly one, right? It should be fine that a custom type introduces multiple keys for its own namespace. Also the text two paragraphs below says

> In summary, the keys for Custom Problem Detail entries
Thanks, clarified this a bit now.

pulls.title: 3GPP stop-gap unbundled
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body:
This PR provides the write-up of the ["unbundled" approach](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/slides-interim-2022-core-05-sessa-problem-details-3gpp-stopgap/) discussed at the interim.

Note that it branches off Carsten's "bundled" PR (#15)

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: I did a little bit of editing.  Comments welcome...
Is that alias thing explained anywhere?
unsigned?

I wanted it to be a trace of the API past, but it's neither necessary nor universally interesting -- leaving alone the fact that the purpose was fully opaque to the reader :-)

I've removed it.
Instead of removing STD94, we may want to use it at the right place.

Although correct, that can be quite confusing.
(We have h32 in EDN for byte strings, but no base32 for numbers.)
Hmm.
Done in [164b1d4](https://github.com/core-wg/core-problem-details/pull/16/commits/164b1d4c930eb3088cdaa257206bd207158cac4d)
:juggling_person:
Ah, you removed the "alias" thing, but not the URI.
OK, we probably need to decide whether this thing is a document, or a data item, or a representation, or...

Here "document" becomes deeply confusing.
(Are you talking about the specification or the data item...)
ISTM that this MUST is only enforceable for registered (uint) keys where the registration procedure imposes the check.
Indeed, but interoperability requirements don't need to be "enforceable"...
Agree, and since you addressed this in [2eac975](https://github.com/core-wg/core-problem-details/pull/16/commits/2eac97594186e4cc158e840d093412b6dedcb84f) we can resolve this comment.
Sometimes one needs to state the obvious 🤣
If we allow URIs in the key, I'm afraid we're back to where we can't easily paint a way toward CoRAL convertability (see also my comments during the last interim).
The URI form is for allowing private use without risks of tainting the global/registered world in case of leakage.

If that's just about replacing private-use uint numbers, that's fine with me (because there is no expectation of convertability with private-use numbers either); maybe I missed it or maybe it can be phrased more explicitly.

```suggestion
consumers of Concise Problem Details are more tightly integrated.
The URI form thus serves a similar function as "private use" numbers would serve if such a range were registered for the unsigned integers.
```

```suggestion
The following example shows how the Hebrew-language string "שלום" is encoded. Note the "rtl" direction expressed by setting the third element in the array to "true".

~~~ cbor-diag
38(["he", "שלום", true])
~~~

~~~ cbor-pretty
d8 26                     # tag(38)
   83                     # array(3)
      62                  # text(2)
         6865             # "he"
      68                  # text(8)
         d7a9d79cd795d79d # "\xD7\xA9\xD7\x9C\xD7\x95\xD7\x9D"
      f5                  # primitive(21)
~~~
```
This line does not work on my machine `¯\_(ツ)_/¯`

ah, and on CircleCI too (the same way as chez moi):
```
cat draft-ietf-core-problem-details.md  | kramdown-rfc2629 --v3 | lib/add-note.py | xml2rfc -q -s 'Setting consensus="true" for IETF STD document' --rfc-base-url https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/ --id-base-url https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/ --cache=/home/idci/.cache/xml2rfc --v2v3 /dev/stdin -o /dev/stdout >draft-ietf-core-problem-details.xml
*** attributes left {"v"=>3}!
---
- Invalid extension stop tag for 'nomarkdown'  found on line 1005 - ignoring it
- No stop tag for extension 'nomarkdown' found on line 814 - ignoring it
- Found invalidly used HTML closing tag for 'section' on line 815
- Found invalidly used HTML closing tag for 'back' on line 817
- Found invalidly used HTML closing tag for 'rfc' on line 1003
- Invalid extension stop tag for 'nomarkdown'  found on line 1005 - ignoring it
Error: Unable to parse the XML document: /dev/stdin
 /dev/stdin: Line 1202: Premature end of data in tag section line 1000
make: *** [lib/main.mk:70: draft-ietf-core-problem-details.xml] Error 1
make: *** Deleting file 'draft-ietf-core-problem-details.xml'

Exited with code exit status 2
```

Do not use circleci.

Do update kramdown-rfc:

`gem update kramdown-rfc`

uhm:
```
╭─~/Documents/github.com/core-wg/core-problem-details on 3gpp-stopgap-unbundled✘✘✘
╰─± gem update kramdown-rfc
Updating installed gems
Nothing to update
```
kramdown-rfc --version should give you 1.6.8

more splendid ascii art

```suggestion
.--------.          .--------.
|  CoAP  |          |  CoAP  |
| Client |          | Server |
'----+---'          '---+----'
     |                  |
     | Request          |
     o----------------->|
     |                  | (failure)
     |<-----------------o
     |   Error Response |
     |      with a CBOR |
     | data item giving |
     |  Problem Details |
     |                  |
```
Any luck with that?
It was returning version 1.5.25, but gem update was happy with the status quo.  I have uninstalled and installed again and now I'm running 1.6.8 which works like a charm.
CDDL type should be text / tag38

Just a note of colour.  What the HTTPbis WG has in its [style guide](https://httpwg.org/admin/editors/style-guide#self-references) about references to self is pretty cute.

BTW, CoRE should have a similar document in the core-wg pages :-)
Maybe we could stick a ref to 8075 here, noting that there may be some sort of URI mapping involved for the `instance` field to make it usable cross-proxy.
Sorry, I was too slow...
Not an incorrect change, but makes we wonder: captions tend to be telegram style (not the app :-), so leaving out articles generally should be OK.

pulls.title: Editorial suggestions
pulls.author: akeranen
pulls.body: Couple of editorial suggestions based on WGLC review

pulls.title: Ad review
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body: Start collecting changes from AD review

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: LGTM.  I've left a small editorial suggestion.

comments.body:
the editorial flow is a bit sub-optimal.  What about:

```suggestion
{{fig-example-custom-with-uri}} shows an example (in CBOR diagnostic notation)
of a custom extension using a URI as `custom-problem-detail-entries` key.
```

pulls.title: Changes based on opsdir review (Joel Jaeggli)
pulls.author: cabo

comments.body: another exception is that of a node that needs to avoid to accidentally forward potentially privacy-sensitive info.

It sounds like an pretty intricate way of just saying:
```suggestion
The "ignore-unknown rule" discussed in the introduction to
{{sec-new-attributes}} applies fully.
```
no? 😄

Well, this sentence is a lead-in to specifically discussing ignore-unknown *inside* a CPDe.
So I don't think the simplified form helps as much.

Removing _"fully"_ from the suggested text could do the trick?

Stepping back a bit: I have troubles making sense of _"[...] can help with including additional information."_.

I think what we are trying to tell the reader is: "apply ignore-unknown when dealing with extensions found in CPDe".  If so, the way the text flows is not conducive to quick and unambiguous grasp of the concept.
I think we are trying to explain you don't have to overdo the evolution of a CPDe because you always can make a new one.
Then we probably should say exactly so :-)
Addressed in 76fe25d

I think we do.  Note that this is text that is directed at the person who wants to evolve a CPDe definition; if it were about handling evolved definitions, it would indeed be redundant.

I tried to make this context more accessible in adb7076

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: I think this is an excellent idea.

comments.body: That was my knee-jerk reaction too.  If we really wanted an unknown value to be ignored we should be more explicit in the defining CDDL, allowing `any` as an alternative to the `uint` array -- subordinate to a future feature extension.
OK, I removed this paragraph.

pulls.title: Address both Yoav's concerns about the security considerations...
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body: ... section and Harald's observations about privacy considerations.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: 🚢 it!

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: Great stuff.  Minor editorial comment that you may ignore.

comments.body:
I would rephrase this as an actual recommendation:
```suggestion
Privacy-sensitive information in the problem details SHOULD
NOT be obscured in ways that might lead to misclassification as
non-sensitive (e.g., by base64-encoding).
```

redacted is not quite the word I'd use here... This is more about the original inclusion of information that is obscured.  Redacting should be done by removing, not by obscuring, but that is a different consideration.

👀 at the dictionary: redacted can mean "obscured" but also "censored".  We only want to talk about the former here, so you are right "obscured" is the right term. (Suggested text modified accordingly).

pulls.title: Address IANA comment on Section 5.2 (now Section 6.2).
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body: This is a minimal change to address the observation in the IANA comments.

comments.body:
```suggestion
as close to first-come-first-served as reasonably achievable, but
```
Not sure this is necessary
I wrote this mainly to fend of the knee-jerk "but this is like specification required, why don't you use that?".
mmm, reminds me of St Jerome's letter 4: _"[...] dum excusare credis, accusas"_, but OK :-)
